is a coastal town in the

First named in 1801 by a French explorer, the town emerged in the 1950s as a growing rock lobster (crayfish) export industry a semi-permanent community of fishermen. The town was little more that a ramble of corrugated iron shacks and boat sheds till the 1980s when a tourist industry developed.
Jurien Bay is a 2.5hr drive from
A daily TransWA service will only get you as far as the turn off on Brand Hwy. From there you are on your own.

The quickest way up the coast is along the Indian Ocean Drive following the coast past Lancelin, Cervantes
.  Alternativly travel the

value: - Covering the stretch of ocean off the coast including a number of islands. Among the sealife are sea lions, dolphins and the occasional migrating whale. Activities on the water is only with your own boat or from the shore.

- An old wooden jetty has been removed and replaced with a much safer jetty.  The old wooden pilons have been used as an artistic feature near the playground. Free gas BBQs are available on the grassed park.

content=A 15min drive out of town is an important nature reserve for flora conservation. The sandy hills are blanketed by over 900 species of plants including several species, some endangered, not found elsewhere. Mount Lesueur provides a good view of the bay.
content=A trail runs from the jetty to Dynamite Bay with some great views of the bay.
- The commercial fishing industry is only interested in the high value crayfish, leaving plenty of dhufish, snapper and groper for the more casual angler.
content=Hack away on a golf course in the dunes that features some gigantic sand traps
- A string of islands surrounded with limestone reefs honeycombed with caves provide plenty of opportunity to get wet.

Seaside Cafe - inside the IGA Shopping Centre

- 45 minutes south of Jurien Bay is the otherworldly limestone pillars.
